positive_phenotypes: The patient presents with infantile-onset, Levodopa-responsive Parkinsonism, which is a clinical hallmark of Parkinson's disease.
The patient exhibited infantile-onset Parkinsonism and infantile leukoencephalopathy.

The patient has infantile-onset Levodopa-responsive Parkinsonism and late-onset neurodegeneration. The first family carried one of the alleles found in our patient (p.Trp13Gly), along with a frameshift mutation predicted to result in loss of function; the latter may account for the more severe intellectual disability seen in the affected siblings.
None of the provided reports mentioned specific clinical phenotypes associated with positive probands.

quote_snippets: compound heterozygous mutations in WARS2 (p.Trp13Gly, p.Ser228Trp)
infantile-onset, Levodopa-responsive Parkinsonism at the age of 2 years
decreased steady-state WARS2 protein and normal OXPHOS content
mitochondrial proliferation without obvious respiratory chain deficiencies
The p.Trp13Gly variant is present in the ExAC database with an allelic frequency of 0.003383 and is not predicted to be extremely deleterious.
However, its location in the mitochondrial localization signal of the protein gives it functional relevance.

The patient was compound heterozygous for two variants in the WARS2 gene: a missense variant c.37T>G (p.Trp13Gly) inherited from his mother and a missense variant c.683C>G (p.Ser228Trp) inherited from his father.
Muscle biopsy analysis A quadriceps muscle biopsy had non-specific changes including mild variation in fiber size with rare atrophic fiber, and normal COX and SDH stains.

Muscle electron microscopy demonstrated well pre-preserved z-bands and fibrils with minimally increased subsarcolemmal mitochondria, many which were mitochondria and some that vary in shape without paracrystalline inclusions.
Mitochondrial DNA content by quantitative polymerase chain reaction (qPCR) analysis was 76% of age- and tissue-matched control.
The association of the patient’s WARS2 variants to Parkinsonism or PD may be further clarified by systematically interrogating available cohorts for such mutations.

MRI imaging at the time of our evaluation revealed a structurally normal study without evidence of abnormal mineral or metal deposition in the deep brain nuclei or leukoencephalopathy, but rather minimal non-specific atrophy.
